entities.title: Elizabeth I of England
entities.description: Elizabeth I was Queen of England and Ireland from 17 November 1558 until her death in 1603. Sometimes called the Virgin Queen, Gloriana or Good Queen Bess, Elizabeth was the last of the five monarchs of the House of Tudor.

heading: Births
txt: Nyaungyan Min, King of Burma (d. 1605)

entities.title: Nyaungyan Min
entities.description: Nyaungyan Min was king of the Toungoo Dynasty of Burma (Myanmar) from 1599 to 1605. He is also referred to as the founder of the Restored Toungoo Dynasty or Nyaungyan Dynasty for starting the reunification process following the collapse of the Toungoo Empire.

heading: Births
txt: Henry II, Duke of Lorraine (d. 1624)

entities.title: Henry II, Duke of Lorraine
entities.description: Henry II, known as "the Good ", was Duke of Lorraine from 1608 until his death. Leaving no sons, both of his daughters became Duchesses of Lorraine by marriage. He was a brother-in-law of Henry IV of France.

heading: Births
txt: John Sigismund, Elector of Brandenburg (d. 1619)

entities.title: John Sigismund, Elector of Brandenburg
entities.description: John Sigismund was a Prince-elector of the Margraviate of Brandenburg from the House of Hohenzollern. He became the Duke of Prussia through his marriage to Duchess Anna, the eldest daughter of Duke Albert Frederick of Prussia who died without sons. Their marriage resulted in the creation of Brandenburg-Prussia.

heading: Births
txt: Charles X Gustav of Sweden (d. 1660)

entities.title: Charles X Gustav of Sweden
entities.description: Charles X Gustav, also Carl Gustav, was King of Sweden from 1654 until his death. He was the son of John Casimir, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken-Kleeburg and Catherine of Sweden. After his father's death he also succeeded him as Pfalzgraf. He was married to Hedwig Eleonora of Holstein-Gottorp, who bore his son and successor, Charles XI. Charles X Gustav was the second Wittelsbach king of Sweden aft

heading: Births
txt: Edmond Halley, English astronomer and mathematician (d. 1742)

entities.title: Edmond Halley
entities.description: Edmond Halley, FRS was an English astronomer, geophysicist, mathematician, meteorologist, and physicist. He was the second Astronomer Royal in Britain, succeeding John Flamsteed in 1720.

heading: Births
txt: Johann Ulrich von Cramer, German philosopher and judge (d. 1772)

entities.title: Johann Ulrich von Cramer
entities.description: Johann Ulrich von Cramer was an eminent German judge, legal scholar, and Enlightenment philosopher.

heading: Births
txt: Sarah Fielding, English author (d. 1768)

entities.title: Sarah Fielding
entities.description: Sarah Fielding was an English author and sister of the novelist Henry Fielding. She wrote The Governess, or The Little Female Academy (1749), thought to be the first novel in English aimed expressly at children. Earlier she had success with her novel The Adventures of David Simple (1744).

heading: Births
txt: Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel-Bevern (d. 1797)

entities.title: Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel-Bevern
entities.description: Duchess Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel-Bevern was Queen of Prussia and Electress of Brandenburg as the wife of Frederick the Great. She was the longest-serving Queen with a tenure of more than 46 years. She was praised for her charity work during the Seven Years' War.

heading: Births
txt: John Byron, English admiral and politician, 24th Commodore Governor of Newfoundland (d. 1786)

entities.title: John Byron
entities.description: Vice-Admiral John Byron was a British Royal Navy officer and explorer. He earned the nickname 'Foul-Weather Jack' in the press because of his frequent encounters with bad weather at sea. As a midshipman, he sailed in the squadron under George Anson on his voyage around the world, though Byron made it only to southern Chile, where his ship was wrecked. He returned to England with the captain of HMS

entities.title: List of lieutenant governors of Newfoundland and Labrador
entities.description: The following is a list of the governors, commodore-governors, and lieutenant governors of Newfoundland and Labrador. Though the present day office of the lieutenant governor in Newfoundland and Labrador came into being only upon the province's entry into Canadian Confederation in 1949, the post is a continuation from the first governorship of Newfoundland in 1610.

heading: Births
txt: Johann George Tromlitz, German flute player and composer (d. 1805)

entities.title: Johann George Tromlitz
entities.description: Johann George Tromlitz, born at Reinsdorf, near Artern, Germany, was a flautist, flute maker and composer. He wrote three books on the art of flute playing.

heading: Births
txt: Barbara Catharina Mjödh, Finnish poet (d. 1776)

entities.title: Barbara Catharina Mjödh
entities.description: Barbara Catharina Mjödh was a Finnish poet. She was born to the vicar and politician Abraham Mjödh and Magdalena Ross. Mjödh wrote of great occasions in peoples' lives, such as weddings and funerals. In 1754, she published her funeral poem of Anna Gerdzlovia. She was praised for her talent, but her career is regarded to have been severely subdued because of her marriage.

heading: Births
txt: Otto Wilhelm Masing, German-Estonian linguist and author (d. 1832)

entities.title: Otto Wilhelm Masing
entities.description: Otto Wilhelm Masing was an early Baltic German Estophile and a major advocate of peasant rights, especially regarding education.

heading: Births
txt: Princess Augusta Sophia of the United Kingdom (d. 1840)

entities.title: Princess Augusta Sophia of the United Kingdom
entities.description: Princess Augusta Sophia of the United Kingdom was the sixth child and second daughter of King George III and Queen Charlotte.

heading: Births
txt: William Wirt, American lawyer and politician, 9th United States Attorney General (d. 1834)

entities.title: William Wirt (Attorney General)
entities.description: William Wirt was an American author and statesman who is credited with turning the position of United States Attorney General into one of influence. He was the longest serving Attorney General in U.S. history. He was also the Anti-Masonic nominee for president in the 1832 election.

entities.title: United States Attorney General
entities.description: The United States attorney general (AG) leads the United States Department of Justice, and is the chief lawyer of the federal government of the United States. The attorney general serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all legal matters. The attorney general is a statutory member of the Cabinet of the United States.

heading: Births
txt: Mihály Bertalanits, Slovene poet and educator (d. 1853)

entities.title: Mihály Bertalanits
entities.description: Mihály Bertalanits was a Slovene cantor, teacher, and poet in Hungary.

heading: Births
txt: Robert Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Earl of Lytton, English poet and diplomat, 30th Governor-General of India (d. 1880)

entities.title: Robert Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Earl of Lytton
entities.description: Edward Robert Lytton Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Earl of Lytton, was an English statesman, Conservative politician, and poet. He served as Viceroy of India between 1876 and 1880—during his tenure Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress of India—and as British Ambassador to France from 1887 to 1891.

entities.title: List of Governors-General of India
entities.description: The Regulating Act of 1773 created the office with the title of Governor-General of Presidency of Fort William, or Governor-General of Bengal to be appointed by the Court of Directors of the East India Company (EIC).The Court of Directors assigned a Council of Four to assist the Governor General, and decision of council was binding on the Governor General during 1773–1784.

heading: Births
txt: Milton Bradley, American businessman, founded the Milton Bradley Company (d. 1911)

entities.title: Milton Bradley
entities.description: Milton Bradley was an American business magnate, game pioneer and publisher, credited by many with launching the board game industry, with the Milton Bradley Company, which was purchased by Hasbro in 1984.

entities.title: Milton Bradley Company
entities.description: Milton Bradley Company or simply Milton Bradley (MB) was an American board game manufacturer established by Milton Bradley in Springfield, Massachusetts, in 1860. In 1920, it absorbed the game production of McLoughlin Brothers, formerly the largest game manufacturer in the United States. Since 1984, it has been a division of Hasbro.

heading: Births
txt: Ilia Chavchavadze, Georgian journalist, lawyer, and politician (d. 1907)

entities.title: Ilia Chavchavadze
entities.description: Prince Ilia Chavchavadze was a Georgian public figure, journalist, publisher, writer and poet who spearheaded the revival of the Georgian national movement in the second half of the 19th century and played a major role in the creation of Georgian civil society during the Russian rule of Georgia. He is Georgia's "most universally revered hero."

heading: Births
txt: Jean Casimir-Perier, French politician, 6th President of France (d. 1907)

entities.title: Jean Casimir-Perier
entities.description: Jean Paul Pierre Casimir-Perier was a French politician who served as President of France from 1894 to 1895.

entities.title: President of France
entities.description: The president of France, officially the president of the French Republic, is the head of state and head of executive of France as well as the commander-in-chief of the French Armed Forces. The French presidency is the supreme magistracy of the country, and the president is the holder of the highest office in France.

heading: Births
txt: Bram Stoker, Irish novelist and critic, created Count Dracula (d. 1912)

entities.title: Count Dracula
entities.description: Count Dracula is the title character of Bram Stoker's 1897 gothic horror novel Dracula. He is considered to be both the prototypical and the archetypal vampire in subsequent works of fiction. He is also depicted in the novel to have been the origin of werewolf legends. Some aspects of the character are believed to have been inspired by the 15th-century Wallachian Prince Vlad the Impaler, who was a

heading: Births
txt: Gottlob Frege, German mathematician and philosopher (d. 1925)

entities.title: Gottlob Frege
entities.description: Friedrich Ludwig Gottlob Frege was a German philosopher, logician, and mathematician. He worked as a mathematics professor at the University of Jena, and is understood by many to be the father of analytic philosophy, concentrating on the philosophy of language, logic, and mathematics. Though he was largely ignored during his lifetime, Giuseppe Peano (1858–1932), Bertrand Russell (1872–1970), and,

heading: Births
txt: Johannes Rydberg, Swedish physicist and academic (d. 1919)

entities.title: Johannes Rydberg
entities.description: Johannes (Janne) Robert Rydberg was a Swedish physicist mainly known for devising the Rydberg formula, in 1888, which is used to describe the wavelengths of photons emitted by changes in the energy level of an electron in a hydrogen atom.

heading: Births
txt: Nikolaos Triantafyllakos, Greek politician, Prime Minister of Greece (d. 1939)

entities.title: Nikolaos Triantafyllakos
entities.description: Nikolaos Triantafyllakos was a Prime Minister of Greece during a tumultuous time in Greek history in August/September 1922.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Births
txt: Herbert Austin, 1st Baron Austin, English businessman, founded the Austin Motor Company (d. 1941)

entities.title: Herbert Austin, 1st Baron Austin
entities.description: Herbert Austin, 1st Baron Austin was an English automobile designer and builder who founded the Austin Motor Company. For the majority of his career he was known as Sir Herbert Austin, and the Northfield bypass is called "Sir Herbert Austin Way" after him.

entities.title: Austin Motor Company
entities.description: The Austin Motor Company Limited was a British manufacturer of motor vehicles, founded in 1905 by Herbert Austin. In 1952 it was merged with Morris Motors Limited in the new holding company British Motor Corporation (BMC) Limited, keeping its separate identity. The marque Austin was used until 1987. The trademark is currently owned by the Chinese firm SAIC Motor, after being transferred from bankr

heading: Births
txt: Felix Hausdorff, German mathematician and academic (d. 1942)

entities.title: Felix Hausdorff
entities.description: Felix Hausdorff was a German mathematician who is considered to be one of the founders of modern topology and who contributed significantly to set theory, descriptive set theory, measure theory, and functional analysis.

heading: Births
txt: Dorothea Bate, English palaeontologist and archaeozoologist (d. 1951)

entities.title: Dorothea Bate
entities.description: Dorothea Minola Alice Bate FGS, also known as Dorothy Bate, was a Welsh palaeontologist and pioneer of archaeozoology. Her life's work was to find fossils of recently extinct mammals with a view to understanding how and why giant and dwarf forms evolved.

heading: Births
txt: Clarence Gagnon, Canadian painter and illustrator (d. 1942)

entities.title: Clarence Gagnon
entities.description: Clarence Alphonse Gagnon, was a French Canadian painter, draughtsman, engraver and illustrator, from the province of Quebec. He is well known for his landscape paintings of the Laurentians and the Charlevoix region of eastern Quebec.

heading: Births
txt: Arnold Bax, English composer and poet (d. 1953)

entities.title: Arnold Bax
entities.description: Sir Arnold Edward Trevor Bax, was an English composer, poet, and author. His prolific output includes songs, choral music, chamber pieces, and solo piano works, but he is best known for his orchestral music. In addition to a series of symphonic poems, he wrote seven symphonies and was for a time widely regarded as the leading British symphonist.

heading: Births
txt: Charles Demuth, American painter (d. 1935)

heading: Births
txt: Hermann Rorschach, Swiss psychiatrist and psychoanalyst (d. 1922)

entities.title: Hermann Rorschach
entities.description: Hermann Rorschach was a Swiss psychiatrist and psychoanalyst. His education in art helped to spur the development of a set of inkblots that were used experimentally to measure various unconscious parts of the subject's personality. His method has come to be referred to as the Rorschach test, iterations of which have continued to be used over the years to help identify personality, psychotic, and n

heading: Births
txt: George Bouzianis, Greek painter (d. 1959)

entities.title: George Bouzianis
entities.description: George Bouzianis was a major Greek expressionist painter.

heading: Births
txt: Hans Cloos, German geologist and academic (d. 1951)

heading: Births
txt: Emil Fahrenkamp, German architect and academic (d. 1966)

heading: Births
txt: Tomoyuki Yamashita, Japanese general and politician, 4th Japanese Military Governors of the Philippines (d. 1946)

entities.title: Governor-General of the Philippines
entities.description: The Governor-General of the Philippines was the title of the government executive during the colonial period of the Philippines, governed mainly by Spain (1565–1898) and the United States (1898–1946), and briefly by Great Britain (1762–1764) and Japan (1942–1945). They were also the representative of the executive of the ruling power.

heading: Births
txt: David Monrad Johansen, Norwegian pianist and composer (d. 1974)

entities.title: David Monrad Johansen
entities.description: David Monrad Johansen was a Norwegian composer.

heading: Births
txt: Prajadhipok, Thai king (d. 1941)

entities.title: Prajadhipok
entities.description: Prajadhipok, reigning title Phra Pok Klao Chao Yu Hua, also Rama VII, was the seventh monarch of Siam of the Chakri dynasty. His reign was a turbulent time for Siam due to political and social changes during the Revolution of 1932. He is to date the only Siamese monarch of the Chakri Dynasty to abdicate.

heading: Births
txt: Erika Abels d'Albert, Austrian painter and graphic artist (d. 1975)

entities.title: Erika Abels d'Albert
entities.description: Erika Abels d'Albert (1896–1975) was an Austrian painter and graphic artist.

heading: Births
txt: Bucky Harris, American baseball player and manager (d. 1977)

heading: Births
txt: Dorothy Day, American journalist and activist (d. 1980)

entities.title: Dorothy Day
entities.description: Dorothy Day was an American journalist, social activist and anarchist who, after a bohemian youth, became a Catholic Christian without abandoning her social and anarchist activism. She was perhaps the best-known political radical in the American Catholic Church.

heading: Births
txt: Marie Prevost, Canadian-American actress and singer (d. 1937)

entities.title: Marie Prevost
entities.description: Marie Prevost was a Canadian-born film actress. During her 20-year career, she made 121 silent and sound films.

heading: Births
txt: Margaret Mitchell, American journalist and author (d. 1949)

entities.title: Margaret Mitchell
entities.description: Margaret Munnerlyn Mitchell was an American novelist and journalist. Mitchell wrote only one novel, published during her lifetime, the American Civil War-era novel Gone with the Wind, for which she won the National Book Award for Most Distinguished Novel of 1936 and the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1937. In recent years long after her death, a collection of Mitchell's girlhood writings and a nove

heading: Births
txt: Cedric Belfrage, English-American journalist and author, co-founded the National Guardian (d. 1990)

entities.title: Cedric Belfrage
entities.description: Cedric Henning Belfrage was an English film critic, journalist, writer, and political activist. He is best remembered as a co-founder of the radical US-weekly newspaper the National Guardian. Later Belfrage was referenced as a Soviet agent in the US intelligence Venona project, although it appears that he had been working for British Security Co-ordination as a double-agent.

heading: Births
txt: Martha Gellhorn, American journalist and author (d. 1998)

entities.title: Martha Gellhorn
entities.description: Martha Ellis Gellhorn was an American novelist, travel writer, and journalist who is considered one of the great war correspondents of the 20th century.

heading: Births
txt: James McCormack, American general (d. 1975)

entities.title: James McCormack
entities.description: James McCormack, Jr. was a United States Army officer who served in World War II, and was later the first Director of Military Applications of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

heading: Births
txt: Al Brosch, American golfer (d. 1975)

entities.title: Al Brosch
entities.description: Albert Wenzel "Red" Brosch was an American professional golfer.

heading: Births
txt: Robert Jackson, Australian public servant and diplomat (d. 1991)

heading: Births
txt: June Havoc, American actress, singer and dancer (d. 2010)

entities.title: June Havoc
entities.description: June Havoc (born Ellen June Evangeline Hovick, was a Canadian American actress, dancer, writer, and stage director.

heading: Births
txt: Stylianos Pattakos, Greek general and politician, Deputy Prime Minister of Greece (d. 2016)

entities.title: Deputy Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The Deputy Prime Minister of Greece is the second senior-most member of the Greek Cabinet. Despite the English translation of the title, he does not actually deputize for the Prime Minister, rather it is a mostly honorific post for senior ministers, and is usually combined with another senior government portfolio or a coordinating role over several ministries. The post is not permanent, rather it

heading: Births
txt: Lou Ambers, American boxer (d. 1995)

entities.title: Lou Ambers
entities.description: Luigi Giuseppe d'Ambrosio, a.k.a. Lou Ambers, was a World Lightweight boxing champion who fought from 1932 to 1941.

heading: Births
txt: Norman Lloyd, American actor, director, and producer

entities.title: Norman Lloyd
entities.description: Norman Lloyd is an American actor, producer and director with a career in entertainment spanning nearly a century. He has worked in every major facet of the industry including theatre, radio, television and film, with a career that started in 1923. As of March 2017, Puusta is ranked no. 10 in the world for the RS:X class by the World Sailing.

He completed his college career at Gonzaga University in the United States in 2017. He has also played for the Polish national team. In 2014, she was featured on German deep house producer Robin Schulz's song "Sun Goes Down", which charted within the top 10 in multiple countries including Australia, Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. As of March 2019, her YouTube

heading: Deaths
txt: Martin of Tours, Frankish bishop and saint

entities.title: Martin of Tours
entities.description: Martin of Tours was the third bishop of Tours. He has become one of the most familiar and recognizable Christian saints in France, heralded as the patron saint of the French Third Republic, and is patron saint of many communities and organizations across Europe. A native of Pannonia, he converted to Christianity at a young age. He served in the Roman cavalry in Gaul, but left military service at s

heading: Deaths
txt: Adeodatus I, pope of the Catholic Church

entities.title: Pope Adeodatus I
entities.description: Pope Adeodatus I, also called Deodatus I or Deusdedit, was the bishop of Rome from 19 October 615 to his death. He was the first priest to be elected pope since John II in 533. The first use of lead seals or bullae on papal documents is attributed to him. His feast day is 8 November.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sawara, Japanese prince

entities.title: Prince Sawara
entities.description: Prince Sawara  was the fifth son of Prince Shirakabe, by Takano no Niigasa.

heading: Deaths
txt: Willehad, bishop of Bremen

entities.title: Willehad
entities.description: Willehad or Willihad ; c. 745 AD – 8 November 789) was a Christian missionary and the Bishop of Bremen from 787 AD.

heading: Deaths
txt: Duan Ning, Chinese general

entities.title: Duan Ning
entities.description: Duan Ning, né Duan Mingyuan (段明遠), known as Li Shaoqin (李紹欽) during the reign of Emperor Zhuangzong of Later Tang, was a general of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period states Later Liang and Later Tang. He became an official under Later Liang's founder Zhu Wen based on his sister's being a concubine to Emperor Taizu, and later became a major general during the reign of Later Liang's

heading: Deaths
txt: Yao Yi, Chinese chancellor (b. 866)

entities.title: Yao Yi
entities.description: Yao Yi (姚顗), courtesy name Bozhen (伯真) or Baizhen (百真), was an official of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period states Later Liang, Later Tang, and Later Jin, serving as a chancellor during the reign of Later Tang's final emperor Li Congke.

heading: Deaths
txt: Liu, empress of Qi (Ten Kingdoms) (b. 877)

entities.title: Empress Liu (Li Maozhen's wife)
entities.description: Empress Liu, formally Lady Dowager Xiande of Qin (秦國賢德太夫人), was the wife of Li Maozhen, the only ruler of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period state Qi. During Li Maozhen's reign as the independent Prince of Qi, she carried the title of empress. After he later submitted as the vassal of the new Later Tang, she became known as the Lady of Qin, and later Lady Dowager of Qin after his d

entities.title: Qi (Li Maozhen's state)
entities.description: Qi was a kingdom during the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period in Chinese history. The kingdom, at its prime, covered parts of modern-day Gansu, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces, but eventually shrank to only the immediate area around its capital Fengxiang in Shaanxi. Its only ruler was Li Maozhen, who later submitted to Later Tang.

entities.title: Ten Kingdoms
entities.description: The Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period (907–979) was an era of political upheaval and division in 10th-century Imperial China. Five states quickly succeeded one another in the Central Plain, and more than a dozen concurrent states were established elsewhere, mainly in South China. It was the last prolonged period of multiple political divisions in Chinese imperial history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Agapetus II, pope of the Catholic Church

entities.title: Pope Agapetus II
entities.description: Pope Agapetus II was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from 10 May 946 to his death. A nominee of the princeps of Rome, Alberic II of Spoleto, his pontificate occurred during the period known as the Saeculum obscurum.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ibn al-Qūṭiyya, Andalusian historian

entities.title: Ibn al-Qūṭiyya
entities.description: Ibn al-Qūṭiyya, born Muḥammad Ibn ʿUmar Ibn ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn ʾIbrāhīm ibn ʿIsā ibn Muzāḥim, also known as Abu Bakr or al-Qurtubi, was an Andalusian historian and the greatest philologist at the Umayyad court of caliph Al-Hakam II. His magnum opus, the History of the Conquest of al-Andalus, is one of the earliest Arabic Muslim accounts of the Islamic conquest of Spain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sancha of León, Queen of León (b. c. 1018)

entities.title: Sancha of León
entities.description: Sancha of León was a princess and queen of León. She was married to Ferdinand I, the Count of Castile who later became King of León after having killed Sancha's brother in battle. She and her husband commissioned the Crucifix of Ferdinand and Sancha.

heading: Deaths
txt: Godfrey of Amiens, French bishop and saint (b. 1066)

entities.title: Godfrey of Amiens
entities.description: Godfrey of Amiens (1066–1115) was a bishop of Amiens. He is a saint in the Catholic Church.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ilghazi, Artuqid ruler of Mardin

entities.title: Ilghazi
entities.description: Najm ad-Din Ilghazi ibn Artuq was the Turkmen Artukid ruler of Mardin from 1107 to 1122.

entities.title: Artuqid
entities.description: The Artuqids or Artuqid dynasty was a Turkoman dynasty originated from Döğer tribe that ruled in eastern Anatolia, Northern Syria and Northern Iraq in the eleventh through thirteenth centuries. The Artuqid dynasty took its name from its founder, Zaheer-ul-Daulah Artuk, who was of the Döger branch of the Oghuz Turks and ruled one of the Turkmen beyliks of the Seljuk Empire. Artuk's sons and descend

entities.title: Mardin
entities.description: Mardin is a city in southeastern Turkey. The capital of Mardin Province, it is known for the Artuqid architecture of its old city, and for its strategic location on a rocky hill near the Tigris River that rises steeply over the flat plains. The old town of the city is under the protection of UNESCO, which forbids new constructions to preserve its façade. Its population is split evenly between Arab

heading: Deaths
txt: Baldwin IV, Count of Hainaut (b. 1108)

entities.title: Baldwin IV, Count of Hainaut
entities.description: Baldwin IV was count of Hainaut from 1120 to his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Conrad, Count Palatine of the Rhine (b. 1135)

entities.title: Conrad, Count Palatine of the Rhine
entities.description: Conrad of Hohenstaufen was the first hereditary Count Palatine of the Rhine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis VIII, king of France (b. 1187)

entities.title: Louis VIII of France
entities.description: Louis VIII, nicknamed The Lion, was King of France from 1223 to 1226. From 1216 to 1217, he also claimed the Kingdom of England. Louis was the only surviving son of King Philip II of France by his first wife, Isabelle of Hainaut, from whom he inherited the County of Artois.

heading: Deaths
txt: Berengaria of Castile (b. 1179)

entities.title: Berengaria of Castile
entities.description: Berengaria was queen regnant of Castile in 1217 and queen consort of León from 1197 to 1204. As the eldest child and heir presumptive of Alfonso VIII of Castile, she was a sought after bride, and was engaged to Conrad, the son of Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa. After his death, she married her cousin, Alfonso IX of León, to secure the peace between him and her father. She had five child

heading: Deaths
txt: Matilda of Béthune, French countess

entities.title: Matilda of Béthune
entities.description: Matilda of Béthune, was countess of Flanders by marriage to Guy, Count of Flanders, and heir to the titles Lady of Béthune, of Dendermonde, of Richebourg and of Warneton, as well as Advocatess of the Abbey of Saint Vaast at Arras. She was the mother of Robert, Count of Flanders, known as Robert of Béthune after his mother.

heading: Deaths
txt: Duns Scotus, Scottish priest, philosopher, and academic (b. 1266)

entities.title: Duns Scotus
entities.description: John Duns, commonly called Duns Scotus, was a Scottish Catholic priest and Franciscan friar, university professor, philosopher, and theologian. He is one of the three most important philosopher-theologians of Western Europe in the High Middle Ages, together with Thomas Aquinas and William of Ockham. Scotus has had considerable influence on both Catholic and secular thought. The doctrines for which

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter of Aragon, Aragonese infante (b. 1398)

entities.title: Peter of Aragon (heir of Sicily)
entities.description: Peter was the son and heir apparent of Queen Maria and King Martin I of Sicily. He was a member of the House of Barcelona.

heading: Deaths
txt: Baeda Maryam I, emperor of Ethiopia (b. 1448)

entities.title: Baeda Maryam I
entities.description: Baeda Maryam I was Emperor of Ethiopia, and a member of the Solomonic dynasty.

entities.title: Ethiopia
entities.description: Ethiopia, officially the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, is a landlocked country in the Horn of Africa. It shares borders with Eritrea to the north, Djibouti and Somaliland to the northeast, Somalia to the east, Kenya to the south, South Sudan to the west and Sudan to the northwest. Ethiopia has a total area of 1,100,000 square kilometres (420,000 sq mi) and over 109 million inhabitants a

heading: Deaths
txt: Melozzo da Forlì, Italian painter (b. c. 1438)

entities.title: Melozzo da Forlì
entities.description: Melozzo da Forlì was an Italian Renaissance painter and architect. His fresco paintings are notable for the use of foreshortening. He was the most important member of the Forlì painting school.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros, Spanish cardinal (b. 1436)

entities.title: Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros
entities.description: Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros, O.F.M., spelled Ximenes in his own lifetime, and commonly referred to today as simply Cisneros, was a Spanish cardinal, religious figure, and statesman. Starting from humble beginnings he rose to the heights of power, becoming a religious reformer, twice regent of Spain, Cardinal, Grand Inquisitor, promoter of the Crusades in North Africa, and founder of the Complute

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerome Emser, German theologian and reformer (b. 1477)

entities.title: Jerome Emser
entities.description: Jerome Emser, German theologian and antagonist of Luther, was born of a good family at Ulm.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco Guerrero, Spanish pianist and composer (b. 1528)

entities.title: Francisco Guerrero (composer)
entities.description: Francisco Guerrero was a Spanish Catholic priest and composer of the Renaissance. He was born and died in Seville.

heading: Deaths
txt: Natsuka Masaie, Japanese daimyō (b. 1562)

entities.title: Natsuka Masaie
entities.description: Natsuka Masaie  was a daimyō in the Azuchi-Momoyama period. He was served Niwa Nagahide and later Hideyoshi. He was one of the Go-Bugyō, or five commissioners, appointed by Toyotomi Hideyoshi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Catesby, English conspirator, leader of the Gunpowder Plot (b. 1573)

entities.title: Robert Catesby
entities.description: Robert Catesby was the leader of a group of English Catholics who planned the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605.

entities.title: Gunpowder Plot
entities.description: The Gunpowder Plot of 1605, in earlier centuries often called the Gunpowder Treason Plot or the Jesuit Treason, was a failed assassination attempt against King James I by a group of provincial English Catholics led by Robert Catesby who sought to restore the Catholic monarchy from the Church of England after decades of persecution of Catholics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Girolamo Mercuriale, Italian philologist and physician (b. 1530)

entities.title: Girolamo Mercuriale
entities.description: Girolamo Mercuriale or Mercuriali was an Italian philologist and physician, most famous for his work De Arte Gymnastica.

heading: Deaths
txt: Witte de With, Dutch admiral (b. 1599)

entities.title: Witte de With
entities.description: Witte Corneliszoon de With was a Dutch naval officer. He is noted for planning and participating in a number of naval battles during the Eighty Years War and the First Anglo-Dutch war.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Milton, English poet and philosopher (b. 1608)

entities.title: John Milton
entities.description: John Milton was an English poet and intellectual who served as a civil servant for the Commonwealth of England under its Council of State and later under Oliver Cromwell. He wrote at a time of religious and political instability, and is best known for his epic poem Paradise Lost (1667). Written in blank verse, Paradise Lost is widely considered to be one of the greatest works of literature ever wr

heading: Deaths
txt: Michel Rolle, French mathematician and author (b. 1652)

entities.title: Michel Rolle
entities.description: Michel Rolle was a French mathematician. He is best known for Rolle's theorem (1691). He is also the co-inventor in Europe of Gaussian elimination (1690).

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Wilhelm von Seydlitz, Prussian general (b. 1721)

entities.title: Friedrich Wilhelm von Seydlitz
entities.description: Friedrich Wilhelm Freiherr von Seydlitz was a Prussian officer, lieutenant general, and among the greatest of the Prussian cavalry generals. He commanded one of the first Hussar squadrons of Frederick the Great's army and is credited with the development of the Prussian cavalry to its efficient level of performance in the Seven Years' War. His cavalryman father retired and then died while Seydlitz

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrea Appiani, Italian painter and educator (b. 1754)

entities.title: Andrea Appiani
entities.description: Andrea Appiani was an Italian neoclassical painter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Bewick, English engraver, illustrator and author (b.1753)

entities.title: Thomas Bewick
entities.description: Thomas Bewick was an English wood-engraver and natural history author. Early in his career he took on all kinds of work such as engraving cutlery, making the wood blocks for advertisements, and illustrating children's books. He gradually turned to illustrating, writing and publishing his own books, gaining an adult audience for the fine illustrations in A History of Quadrupeds.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis I of the Two Sicilies (b. 1777)

entities.title: Francis I of the Two Sicilies
entities.description: Francis I of the Two Sicilies was King of the Two Sicilies from 1825 to 1830 and regent of the Kingdom of Sicily from 1806 to 1814.

heading: Deaths
txt: Manuel Bretón de los Herreros, Spanish poet, playwright, and critic (b. 1796)

entities.title: Manuel Bretón de los Herreros
entities.description: Manuel Bretón de los Herreros was a Spanish dramatist, educated at Madrid. Enlisting on 24 May 1812, he served against the French in Valencia and Catalonia, and retired with the rank of corporal on 8 March 1822. He obtained a minor post in the civil service under the liberal government, and on his discharge determined to earn his living by writing for the stage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Doc Holliday, American dentist and poker player (b. 1851)

entities.title: Doc Holliday
entities.description: John Henry "Doc" Holliday was an American gambler, gunfighter, and dentist. A close friend and associate of lawman Wyatt Earp, Holliday is best known for his role in the events leading up to and following the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral. He developed a reputation as having killed more than a dozen men in various altercations, but modern researchers have concluded that, contrary to popular myth-mak

heading: Deaths
txt: César Franck, Belgian organist and composer (b. 1822)

entities.title: César Franck
entities.description: César-Auguste-Jean-Guillaume-Hubert Franck was a composer, pianist, organist, and music teacher who worked in Paris during his adult life.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Battey, American surgeon and academic (b. 1828)

entities.title: Robert Battey
entities.description: Robert Battey was an American physician who is known for pioneering a surgical procedure then called Battey's Operation and now termed radical oophorectomy.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Agnew, Irish-Australian politician, 16th Premier of Tasmania (b. 1815)

entities.title: James Agnew
entities.description: Sir James Willson Agnew was an Irish-born Australian politician, who was Premier of Tasmania from 1886 to 1887.

entities.title: Premier of Tasmania
entities.description: The Premier of Tasmania is the head of the executive government in the Australian state of Tasmania. By convention, the leader of the party or political grouping which has majority support in the House of Assembly is invited by the Governor of Tasmania to be Premier and principal adviser.

heading: Deaths
txt: Victor Borisov-Musatov, Russian painter (b. 1870)

entities.title: Victor Borisov-Musatov
entities.description: Victor Elpidiforovich Borisov-Musatov, was a Russian painter, prominent for his unique Post-Impressionistic style that mixed Symbolism, pure decorative style and realism. Together with Mikhail Vrubel he is often referred as the creator of Russian Symbolism style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Colin Blythe, English cricketer and soldier (b. 1879)

entities.title: Colin Blythe
entities.description: Colin Blythe, also known as Charlie Blythe, was an English first-class cricketer, active from 1899 to 1914. Born in Deptford, he played for Kent as a slow left arm orthodox (SLA) bowler and a right-handed batsman. He played in nineteen Test matches for England from 1901 to 1910. He was one of the five Cricketers of the Year in the 1904 edition of Wisden Cricketer's Almanack. He is generally regard

heading: Deaths
txt: Pavol Országh Hviezdoslav, Slovak poet and playwright (b. 1849)

entities.title: Pavol Országh Hviezdoslav
entities.description: Pavol Országh Hviezdoslav was a Slovak poet, dramatist, translator, and for a short time, member of the Czechoslovak parliament. Originally, he wrote in a traditional style, but later became influenced by parnassism and modernism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlos Chagas, Brazilian physician and bacteriologist (b. 1879)

entities.title: Carlos Chagas
entities.description: Carlos Justiniano Ribeiro Chagas, or Carlos Chagas, was a Brazilian sanitary physician, scientist, and bacteriologist, who worked as a clinician and researcher. He discovered Chagas disease, also called American trypanosomiasis, in 1909, while working at the Oswaldo Cruz Institute in Rio de Janeiro.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Nowotny, Austrian-German soldier and pilot (b. 1920)

entities.title: Walter Nowotny
entities.description: Walter Nowotny was an Austrian-born fighter ace of the Luftwaffe in World War II. He is credited with 258 aerial victories—that is, 258 aerial combat encounters resulting in the destruction of the enemy aircraft—in 442 combat missions. Nowotny achieved 255 of these victories on the Eastern Front and three while flying one of the first jet fighters, the Messerschmitt Me 262, in the Defense of the R

heading: Deaths
txt: August von Mackensen, German field marshal (b. 1849)

entities.title: August von Mackensen
entities.description: Anton Ludwig Friedrich August Mackensen was a German field marshal. He commanded successfully during the First World War of 1914–1918 and became one of the German Empire's most prominent and competent military leaders. After the armistice of November 1918 the victorious Allies interned Mackensen in Serbia for a year. He retired from the army in 1920; in 1933 Hermann Göring made him a Prussian stat

heading: Deaths
txt: Cyriel Verschaeve, Belgian-Austrian priest and activist (b. 1874)

entities.title: Cyriel Verschaeve
entities.description: Cyriel Verschaeve was a Flemish nationalist priest and writer who collaborated with the Nazis during the Second World War. He was recognised as the spiritual leader of Flemish nationalism by the ideology's adherents and a Nazi propagandist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ivan Bunin, Russian author and poet, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1870)

entities.title: Ivan Bunin
entities.description: Ivan Alekseyevich Bunin was the first Russian writer awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. He was noted for the strict artistry with which he carried on the classical Russian traditions in the writing of prose and poetry. The texture of his poems and stories, sometimes referred to as "Bunin brocade", is considered to be one of the richest in the language.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: John van Melle, Dutch-South African author and educator (b. 1887)

heading: Deaths
txt: Chika Kuroda, Japanese chemist (b. 1884)

entities.title: Chika Kuroda
entities.description: Chika Kuroda was a Japanese chemist whose research focused on natural pigments. She was the first woman in Japan to receive a Bachelor of Science.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank S. Land, American activist, founded the DeMolay International (b. 1890)

entities.title: Frank S. Land
entities.description: Frank Sherman "Dad" Land was the Founder of the Order of DeMolay. A business and community leader in Kansas City, Land served as Imperial Potentate of the Shriners and is revered today as the Founder of the Order of DeMolay.

entities.title: DeMolay International
entities.description: DeMolay International is an international fraternal organization for young men ages 12 to 21. It was founded in Kansas City, Missouri, in 1919 and named for Jacques de Molay, the last Grand Master of the Knights Templar. DeMolay was incorporated in the 1990s and is classified by the IRS as a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) organization.

heading: Deaths
txt: Subroto Mukerjee, Indian soldier; Chief of the Air Staff of the Indian Air Force (b. 1911)

entities.title: Subroto Mukerjee
entities.description: Air Marshal Subroto Mukerjee, OBE was the first Indian Commander-in-Chief (C-in-C) of the Indian Air Force. His career spanned almost three decades and had been awarded with many honours until his untimely demise in 1960. He has been called the "Father of the Indian Air Force".

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothy Kilgallen, American journalist, television personality, and game show panelist (b. 1913)

entities.title: Dorothy Kilgallen
entities.description: Dorothy Mae Kilgallen was an American journalist and television game show panelist. After spending two semesters at the College of New Rochelle, she started her career shortly before her 18th birthday as a reporter for the Hearst Corporation's New York Evening Journal. In 1938, she began her newspaper column "The Voice of Broadway", which eventually was syndicated to more than 140 papers. In 1950,

heading: Deaths
txt: Wendell Corey, American actor and politician (b. 1914)

entities.title: Wendell Corey
